item.title: Dad and America
item.description: My dad texted me “happy July 4th” the day of, and it prompted me to think about what it means to be an American.

item.title: The Beliefs We Harbor
item.description: What follows is something that happened in 2017. I wrote about it then for my friends and figure it’s worth reposting here, especially given the current state of affairs on the homefront and in the world.

item.title: Remember What You're Fighting For
item.description: Had a lovely conversation with a woman named Natalie via DialUp, an app that aims to revive the magic and intimacy of phone conversations.

item.title: On Attention and Cleaning One's Ears
item.description: For the past few weeks I noticed some pressure and discomfort on the inside of my right ear upon waking. I didn’t give it much thought and dismissed it as a minor annoyance, but then I realized that the volume on my computer had been gradually raised over the last few weeks, likely to compensate for an increased lack of hearing.

item.title: Weekly
item.description: I started the week in partial limbo. This usually happens when I lack a sense of direction and things to do.

item.title: Graduate School
item.description: It’s been a long process of deliberation, but I’ve decided to attend graduate school at UVM. It wasn’t an easy decision.

item.title: Change
item.description: Change, by definition, is uncomfortable. It asks us to work against the quicksand of comfort, it forces us to relinquish the wornout marks we still wear, it beckons us to surrender to the tumultuous winds of the unknown.

item.title: Superpowers
item.description: A dear friend and I send each other long voice messages when we want to update each other on our lives.

item.title: Emma
item.description: In the airport, a young child from China sitting across me is working on a puzzle. I watch as she pieces the parts together, then realize she’s missing the last one.

item.title: To Hold
item.description: More and more I find myself holding the pain of others. It’s a privileged place to be, to serve as the anchor that people hang onto when the currents of life become too tumultuous to bear, to guide through that necessary journey of self-annihilation before any growth may take place.

item.title: Intensity
item.description: Between every relationship we ever had, have, and will have, there exists a unique configuration of constellations that defines its being.

item.title: Moments
item.description: This is Alyona (and I). We began writing letters to each other over a year ago toward the end of 2018.

item.title: Devotion
item.description: It’s the day I’m supposed to be camping in Joshua Tree, but I find myself driving up the coast instead, hunting for answers.

item.title: Loneliness
item.description: This essay is adopted from one I wrote awhile ago for a science and writing class. All the lonely peopleWhere do they all come from?

item.title: An Ode to Young Adulthood
item.description: There’s this drawing of a banana. Toward the stem it is fresh, premature, and budding with potential; toward the other end it is weathered and well-defined, filled with the hard-earned sweetness and history that a full life bestows.

item.title: Fall 2019
item.description: I’m finally finished with the semester. Soon I’ll be heading home to see my parents, camp in Joshua Tree National Park, and soak in the California sunshine.

item.title: A Recent Trip
item.description: This past Sunday, I tried magic mushrooms for the first time. It wasn’t much – around a gram or so, which is a bit less than what this paper suggests for someone of my body weight – but it was enough to dig up some insights about myself and the nature of the mind.

item.title: Rome
item.description: I recently went to Rome, and it was nothing short of stimulating, sensuous, and overwhelming. From the minimal use of ingredients in Italian cuisine to the incredible works of Michaelangelo and other Roman artists, everywhere you went, everything you touched, tasted and smelled, everything you experienced, it all seemed like some part of a grand plan aimed at steering one’s senses toward a deeper appreciation and understanding of beauty and aesthetics.

item.title: Bearing Witness
item.description: There are 16 of us nestled in the sunlit alcove of the church. I look at the stranger sitting on a navy-blue cushion before me and wonder what she is thinking about.

item.title: The Pale Blue Dot
item.description: Propelled into space in 1977, NASA’s scientific objective of launching the Voyager I was to photograph the planets of the outer solar system.

item.title: Shoreless Seeds and Stardust
item.description: I ventured out onto the lake today, this time beyond the frozen crest that marks the boundary between bay and lake, contemplating the last line of Maria Popova’s Figuring:

item.title: Mary Oliver
item.description: We met in the biting winter nights of my service year in New Hampshire. I listened with full attention as she illuminated the nuances of a world I thought I knew with the written word, hers, words that continue to remind me I am never truly alone, words that continue to show me the world is always at offer to the playground of my imagination.

item.title: Serendipity
item.description: We sift through life without any compasses to guide us through the messy unknown, like aimless treasure hunters searching for diamonds in the dark.

item.title: Forgiveness
item.description: Forgiveness moves us toward a better future by inviting us to look at the past, at the unrelenting, painful ghosts that continue to permeate and darken each of our lives.

item.title: Feelings
item.description: Feelings are fleeting by nature, like the passage of clouds on a warm summer day. Though too often we wear them like immutable masks and declare, “This is me.

item.title: 18: Home
item.description: After Belgium I spent a night in Prague and took a bus to Hungary the next morning. I stayed in Budapest for 10 days with Eszter, the Hungarian I had a crush on at the beginning of this whole adventure.

item.title: 17: The Final Goodbye
item.description: I arrive in Belgium late in the afternoon. The weather is exceptional: half-clouded skies with no reservation of sunlight, a perfect balance of cool and warm.

item.title: 16: Santiago
item.description: “How we spend our days is, of course, how we spend our lives.” –Annie Dillard October 8, 2017 - Day 31 Pedrouzo, Spain.

item.title: 15: Letters Worth Czeching Out
item.description: I wrote these letters to my friend, Stepan, from the Czech Republic. Including them because they might help to create a better picture of my experience.

item.title: 14: Letters to a Camino Soulmate
item.description: These are the emails Marieke and I wrote to each other after she was gone. They might give you a better picture of my Camino experience.

item.title: 13: The Iron Cross
item.description: October 1st, 2017 - Day 25 Dawn. A ridge of silhouettes and gray clouds against the dark expanse. A string of headlamps clambering up a mountain.

item.title: 12: Journal Entries from Day 22 - 24
item.description: September 28, 2017 - Day 22 To be yourself–Easy to say, hard to do.What we think is not ours.What we believe is shaped by others.

item.title: 11: A Sea of Stars
item.description: Day 21 4:30am. I inch out from my sleeping bag like a slug, careful not to disturb the others in the room, pack my things and head downstairs.

item.title: 10: Journal Entries from Day 17 - 20
item.description: September 23, 2017 - Day 17 We are always on the cusp of collapse and redemption. Do we choose to rise, or do we settle and fall?

item.title: 9: An Ode to the Road
item.description: Each and every day I wake and walk with the sun.It starts low, climbing over hillsides, rising slowly.At last it finds its place in the skyand begins to color the Meseta.

item.title: 8: Gone
item.description: I’ve sunken into the depths of an all-too-familiar melancholy. She is gone. I am alone. My emotions swing to the erratic cadence of an unforgiving metronome.

item.title: 7: Goodbye
item.description: Day 15. We’re sitting amid a small cluster of dining tables in the main plaza of Burgos, sipping on wine and eating tapas.

item.title: 6: Sunsets and Soulmates
item.description: “Phil! I have a genius idea. You’re really going to like it.” It’s the 12th day. Marieke, Stepan (a walker from The Czech Republic we met a few days ago), and I go to the top of a hill to catch the sunset.

item.title: 5: The Cusp of Time and Infinity
item.description: In the morning we walk to Pamplona, our first city. I run into Maria and chat with her for a brief moment before running off with the girls to get breakfast.

item.title: 4: Möge die Straße
item.description: Another gray and rainy day. We sleep in and start walking at 8am. After the deep and enlightening conversations of yesterday, we decide to walk in solitude –– together but left to the vicinity of our inner worlds.

item.title: 3: Tea
item.description: Through the window I see Sun-bathed flowers and untouched rock, Blades of grass and untrodden walks, Endless possibility. I ask of you Time

item.title: 2: First Ascent
item.description: I wake to the sound of creaking bunk beds, rustling backpacks, and hushed chatter. 5:30 a.m. Time to go. I put my boots on, pack my sleeping bag, and head downstairs.

item.title: 1: Beginnings
item.description: The Camino de Santiago is a network of pilgrimage routes that ultimately converge on the city of Santiago de Compostela in Northwestern Spain, where the great Saint James is rumored to be buried.

item.description: In May of 2017, while working in a Title I Elementary school in New Hampshire, I read a little fable called “Rebirth” by Kaval Ravikant.
